item.title: [ROO-46] Drag and drop GUI support for creating persistence classes
item.description:
If you can provide a GUI to create persistence class with "click and drop" like workflow it would be good. This would replace the following style of Roo commands:

new persistent class jpa -name ~.domain.Item
add field string -fieldName name -notNull
add field string comments -sizeMax 150
add field number -fieldName price -type java.lang.Float
item.summary: Drag and drop GUI support for creating persistence classes

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment: Will be considered as part of long-term roadmap. There are separate proposals to support UML-based modeling, as well as a related proposal to build a Roo script from an existing database. Another approach would be to provide this functionality with STS, given it already offers a GUI capability and the core Roo project has no intention of releasing it own GUI technology (ie issue ROO-46 would need to be implemented in full or in part by another tool, like an IDE or UML editor).
Options for both UML based modeling and build from existing database would be ideal.

I know andromda is currently trying to solve this sort of problem. Perhaps you can leverage what they've learned during their travels or even provide some integration:

http://www.andromda.org

We heavily use UML in our large DDD-focused implementation effort. It would be great to make this more model driven and facilitate keeping UML and code in sync.
I'm about a day away from completing a tool that round trips between roo and argouml XMI format. If someone can show me how to create a roo plugin it might be useful.

It is important to investigate which profile of UML you would like to use. Using a generic UML profile would open up the pandoras box of ambiguity (UML is known as undefined modeling language in the academics serious about software architechture) I would vote for SysML which borrows things from UML and adds various things to UML and in my opnion far less ambiguous.

I think we should also think along the lines of a GUI tool which deals with components and connectors (ie OSGI modules). Give modelers powerful lego blocks to play with.

Shahzada, I have some images in https://jira.springsource.org/browse/ROO-731
I was working on fixing up the return leg of the conversion (roo script -> UML) but being made redundant distracted me. I was intending to do a vid, as I think it is more compelling, but few people seem to want a modelling GUI. No idea why because we shouldn't have stupid demos where the first thing they do is draw a diagram, and then they say this is how to do it in 4 pages of xml, or a page of rooscript or whatever. How much easier is it to transfer domain knowledge by showing a picture rather than a page of roo script? But I suppose the argument would be to reverse engineer the diagram from the code (even though like contract first webservices the model should be the driver)?

On the return leg I can get all the entities back, but haven't yet worked on the joins between them.
Let me know if you want further detail.

It relies on the Eclipse Modeling Framework (EMF) and the ATL Transformation Language to convert either Eclipse UML2 or Ecore models into Roo scripts. The details of the Roo commands are specified through UML profiles and Ecore annotations, respectively.

Afaik the best approach to this is XML definition ... For instance Liferay portal has an integrated source code generator ( for domain model, dao layer, ddl scripts, remote service layer, etc. etc., everything is generated) based on this http://docs.liferay.com/portal/6.0/definitions/liferay-service-builder_6_0_0.dtd.org.html schema and it is absolutely brilliant, transparent, self-explanatory ....

I think we shouldn't reinvent the wheel, why cannot we take the DBRE way? That's is:

  • To have an UML2 description file than contains the metadata information in XML format, it could be stored and maintained by a Roo add-on
    Is XMI an option?
  • The add-on creates/maintains JPA entities based on that file

Features of this proposal:

  • bi-directional
    • Changes in entities should update the UML2 description file
    • Changes in UML2 description file should update JPA entities
  • UML2 visual designer to update the UML2 description file
  • Use Roo console or write Java code directly as usual
  • Just choose your way
